title: A T-rex appears on an ancient Roman battlefield, and the Romans (numbering 100) have to fight it. Who would win? - Quora

response.answer_text: The bigger question is what do the Romans do with it once it's dead. There would be terror but if they could keep their discipline, then the Romans would have no problem in defeating the T-Rex. Before it got close it would be pierced with enough javelins and arrows to seriously wound it. It might just get close enough to take a chomp out of a few and stomp on a few others, but whilst it's doing that it will be hacked to pieces. If it just appears out of nowhere I suspect 20 soldiers would be sufficient. If they know its coming you can probably half that again or even less and probably take it alive. People like to underestimate just how amazing hunters we are. We are far and away the greatest predators that have ever lived.

The Romans. Each Roman legionnaire has two spears…which they are trained to use as hurling weapons against an enemy. 100 Roman soldiers, therefore, has 200 such spears…few of which would miss a target as large as a T-rex. In fact, a smart Roman commander, such as Julius Caesar…would detail a smaller number…to let fly their spears…and assess the results. Even ten men, using twenty such spears…could seriously injure…if not kill outright, the dinosaur…leaving 90 men with their spears intact to repeat the process, in relays, if necessary. A T-rex is a fearsome predator… but against trained soldiers…even if armed with only spears, swords, and shields, it dies!

The Romans . One hundred pilum would fly at 15 meters killing the T-Rex at once . And if they had a couple scorpions , at one hundred meters the T -Rex would be seriously wounded it’s killed .And to finish ,one hundred gladius would stab the dinosaur to pieces .
Romans. They’d lose a good number, to be sure, but all the wounds sustained from Roman spears would force the Rex to retreat, where it would probably bleed to death.
The Romans should win, unless they panic - something which is not out of the question, to be honest.
